title: Vegetarian hooked on meat after eating a single burger - and then became a BUTCHER
text:
Tammi Jonas (pictured) became a vegetarian in the 1970s after reading Peter Singer's popular book 'Animal Liberation'

A woman who lived as a vegetarian for 10 years craved meat so badly when she was pregnant with her third child she started eating meat again - and became a butcher.

Tammi Jonas, 49, became a vegetarian in the 1970s after reading Peter Singer's popular book 'Animal Liberation' and was shocked to learn about the treatment of farm animals.

For a decade, the Eganstown local, in regional Victoria, committed to a vegetarian diet, but it wasn't until she became pregnant for the third time in her 30s that everything changed.

'I had been pregnant twice before, but this the third time was different and I became dangerously anemic,' she told Daily Mail Australia.

After downing a burger at work one day, the mum-of-three was hooked.

While she admitted it took a while to start eating pork and poultry, Ms Jonas she 'felt fantastic' after eating beef and lamb.

While she admitted it took a while to start eating pork and poultry, Ms Jonas she 'felt fantastic' after eating beef and lamb (pictured: Ms Jonas holding a chunk of meat)

'I felt healthier because I was giving my body what it needed,' she said.

'But I was careful where I got my meat from.'

Coming from a farming family in Oregon before migrating to Australia, Ms Jonas explained she wanted to create a farm and butcher so consumers had the option of choosing ethical options.

'The penny dropped and we realised that we were going to be farmers and, for me, I knew immediately pigs because they are some of the worst treated in industrial systems,' she told 10 Daily.

Ms Jonas explained she wanted to create a farm and butcher so consumers had the option of choosing ethical options (pictured: Ms Jonas holding a large sausage)

Ms Jonas and her husband Stuart have have now been running Jonai Farms and Meatsmiths for eight years.

Ms Jonas describes her farming practices to Daily Mail Australia as ethical and holistic.

She explained there are no harmful chemicals used in her farming practices, and the animals live as they would if they weren't in a farm at all.

'Some people will draw an ethical line that killing is bad,' she said.

'But I don't believe that - I don't think killing an animal for consumption is unethical if it had a good life.'
description: Tammi Jonas, from Eganstown in Victoria, became a vegetarian in the 1970s after reading popular book 'Animal Liberation'. It wasn't until she fell pregnant that it all changed.
authors: Charlotte Karp For Daily Mail Australia
